text: a study found that 80 to 95 percent of
college students procrastinate if this
sounds like you then you've come to the
right place because today we'll go over
four powerful anti-procrastination tips
tip number one learn to accept failure
behavioral psychologist Jr Ferrari and
dmtis conducted a study in 2000 at
DePaul University they gathered a bunch
of students who identified as chronic
procrastinators and instructed them to
solve some math puzzles they separate
the participants into two groups a
serious one and a fun one the serious
group was told that the puzzle would be
used as a test to gauge their abilities
while the fun group was told that the
puzzle was meaningless both groups were
then given free time along with some
games but also some material that could
be used to prepare for the math puzzle
what happened next was very interesting
the serious group spent the majority of
their free time playing around with the
games spending very little to no time
preparing while the fun group spent the
majority of their time preparing the
study concluded that procrastinators
often sabotage themselves when faced
with tasks which they could fail you see
if the participants in the serious group
tried hard and failed to solve the
puzzle they would be hit with a wave of
negative emotions it would suggest that
they were dumb or incompetent on the
other hand for the fun group the puzzle
was meaningless so there was nothing to
fail at not being able to solve the
puzzle would not have any negative
implications and because there was no
possibility for negative emotions they
did not feel the need to procrastinate
Ferrari explained that chronic
procrastinators would rather have other
people think they lack effort than lack
ability in other words they would prefer
to be thought of as lazy than as a
failure how can we apply this to our
lives well if we can reframe how we look
at failure if we can look at it as an
opportunity to grow and learn as
compared to it being proof that we are
losers who will never amount to anything
then we should feel less of a need to
avoid the work in the first place
alternatively we could take things less
seriously and realize that failure in a
test or project doesn't really mean
anything in the grand scheme of things
of course this is easier said than done
but it is some something to think about
moving on to tip number two increasing
your self-compassion a study was
conducted in 2010 by Michael Woll and Dr
pitchell they interviewed 119 students
before two major tests the researchers
found that students who forgave
themselves for procrastinating on the
first test were much less likely to
procrastinate on the second test another
study conducted in 2012 found that
procrastinators tended to have higher
stress and lower levels of
self-compassion both of these studies
suggest that self-compassion reduces the
amount of negative emotions that
students feel which as we know from tip
number one is a major reason why many of
us procrastinate in the first place when
you are quick to forgive yourself for
making mistakes you are less likely to
spend long periods of time waist deep in
negative emotions you'll quickly brush
the mistake off and move on with your
life now how exactly do we increase our
self-compassion well for one a large
part of self-compassion can come from
the belief that no one is perfect we are
all flawed beings and that's okay that's
just how things are instead of beating
yourself up for making a mistake Sim
simply make a note of it think about
what you can do next time to avoid
messing up and move on an alternative
strategy that can be used to increase
your self-compassion is to write down a
list of positive things about yourself
or things that you've done every week or
so as cheesy as it sounds it can work
because it forces you to look at
yourself in a positive light also you
should spend less time on social media
influencers often pretend that they live
picture-perfect lives when we see this
we start to believe that this lifestyle
is far more common than it actually is
which makes us feel worse about
ourselves and the current situation that
we are in I suggest avoiding social
media as much as possible and primarily
using it for either communication with
friends or business if you are
struggling with feelings of self-worth
and self-compassion it is always a good
idea to speak with a therapist moving on
to tip number three the adoption of the
smartphone has made it easy for us to
stack multiple stimulating activities on
top of each other you can now play a
video game while listening to a podcast
and eat junk food all at the same time
each of these activities on their own
releases a large amount of dopamine but
when you combine the three you end up
releasing much much more exposure to
high levels of dopamine for long periods
of time lowers your Baseline level of
dopamine it's almost like your body
starts to build an immunity to it and
you'll find it harder to feel excited
for the simpler things in life including
doing the work you know you need to do
which is why tip number three is to
avoid dopamine stacking try your best to
avoid doing multiple stimulating
activities at the same time the next
time you have a meal try to enjoy the
meal instead of pulling out your phone
and watching YouTube the next time you
watch a show put away your phone and
just focus on the show in front of you
you get the idea by doing this you will
gradually increase your Baseline levels
of dopamine over time this may be hard
at first you might feel bored if you're
not stacking but over time it will get
easier as your Baseline levels of
dopamine recover and things start to
feel less boring you could also try a
dopamine fast where you stay away from
all over stimulating activities for a
day doing so can speed up the recovery
if you'd like to learn more about
dopamine fast you can check out a video
I did on the subject in the description
box below and finally we have tip number
four trick yourself this is a
psychological trick that we sourced from
Dr Tim pitchell a psychologist and
expert on procrastination here's how it
works when you start a task think about
the next step as something that you may
or may not do you can tell yourself I
won't do that but if I did how would I
do it so for example let's say you have
to pack a suitcase but you've been
putting it off you could trick Yourself
by thinking okay I'm not going to pack
the bag but if I did what would my first
step be maybe it's to find the suitcase
and open it up if so where is that
suitcase right now by thinking about the
path of execution you will have
essentially tricked yourself to start
and motivation tends to follow action so
once you get started you'll find it much
easier to get the ball rolling and
finish the rest of the task fighting
procrastination is important but being
smart with your time is even more
important which is why one of the best
things to consider is if school is even
worth your time as there are many other
options out there this is why I suggest
you check out our video on the top three
remote careers that are currently in
high demand you can find it in the
description box below these are all
careers that are high paying where you
can get hired in under six months hope
this video was helpful besides that stay
tuned
